metadata.case_name: Amrit Lal Berry & Anr. v. Union of India & Ors.
metadata.case_number: Writ Petition Nos. 463 of 1971 and 2004 of 1973

facts.text: Amrit Lal Berry appointed Inspector in Central Excise Collectorate at Delhi by orders dated 22-11-1948, posted at Ferozepur on 4-12-1948.
Ministry of Home Affairs issued Office Memorandum dated 22-6-1949 stating seniority of existing Govt. servants determined by date of appointment and number from date of confirmation.
Amrit Lal Berry confirmed in permanent post under order dated 5-5-1956 with effect from 1-7-1955.
Narinder Singh, matriculate, appointed 7-2-1949, confirmed retrospectively from 1-7-1953; date of birth 24-7-1911 vs. petitioner's 5-4-1925.
Office Memorandum dated 22-12-1959 altered rule; seniority determined from dates of confirmation; new seniority lists prepared.
Seniority list issued in 1958 prepared per 1949 memo; petitioner assigned seniority accordingly.
Petitioner Amrit Lal Berry given senior grade only on 8-12-1967, claims should have been from 21-3-1961.
Twelve juniors promoted as Superintendents in 1970-1971 per impugned seniority list of 1-7-1967.
Petitioner Amrit Lal Berry made representations dated 6-3-1965 and 13-8-1971, no replies received.
Writ Petition No. 463/71 filed by Amrit Lal Berry on 9-12-1971.
N. Kapur and 14 others appointed as Inspectors from 15-5-1944 to 19-1-1950; confirmations from 1-7-1956 to 1-12-1962; senior grade entry from 29-3-1965 to 22-11-1971.
K. N. Kapur seniority dropped from No. 32 to No. 252 in 1961 list.
Office Memorandum dated 22-7-1972 issued by Dept. of Personnel interpreting Ravi Varma judgment; restores pre-1959 seniority from 4-1-1972 without disturbing prior confirmations/promotions.
Office Memoranda dated 16-3-1973 and 17-3-1973 issued by Ministry of Finance.
Amrit Lal Berry did not pass prescribed departmental examination until November 1954; confirmed after passing on vacancy occurrence.
Union of India v. M. Ravi Varma decided on 4-1-1972 holding 1959 memo prospective, not applying to pre-1959 appointees.

legal_issues.text: Whether Office Memorandum dated 22-7-1972 correctly interprets Ravi Varma judgment and gives effect to 1949 seniority rule without violating Article 16.
Whether petitioners' fundamental rights under Article 16(1) violated by seniority lists based on confirmation dates post-1959 and promotions of juniors.
Whether petitions barred by laches, acquiescence, and failure to show specific denial of equality of opportunity.

petitioner_arguments.text: Seniority should be per 1949 memo by length of service; 1959 memo does not apply retrospectively per Ravi Varma; juniors wrongly promoted due to illegal 1967/1961 lists.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Office Memo 22-6-1949; Union of India v. M. Ravi Varma; Article 16

petitioner_arguments.text: 1972 memo misinterprets Ravi Varma by not granting consequential past benefits like promotions, arrears; quash 1972, 1973 memos.

respondent_arguments.text: No violation of law or fundamental rights; 1972 memo balances 1949 rule with non-disturbance of past confirmations/promotions; petitions barred by laches, acquiescence, misjoinder.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 16; Ravi Varma; Rabindra Nath Bose v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: Petitions lack specific averments of fundamental rights violation; no demand and refusal for mandamus; justifiable discrimination e.g., exam failure delayed confirmation.

court_reasoning.text: 1959 memo prospective per Ravi Varma; 1972 memo restores pre-1959 seniority from 4-1-1972 without disturbing prior confirmations/promotions to protect acquired rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 1972 memo gives reasonable effect to Ravi Varma consistent with equity.

court_reasoning.text: No clear violation of Article 16(1); equality requires showing unjustifiable denial on specific occasions; petitioner's delayed confirmation due to exam failure justifiable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Confirmation not solely by length of service; other conditions apply.

court_reasoning.text: Petitions barred by inordinate delay; equitable rights accrued to promoted juniors; laches disentitles relief under Article 32.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot disturb long-standing promotions; Rabindra Nath Bose applies.

holdings.text: 1972 memo constitutionally valid as interpreted: applies 1949 rule prospectively from 4-1-1972, reconsiders cases subject to vacancies, without undoing past actions.
No violation of Article 16(1) established; petitions fail for lack of specificity and laches.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. M. Ravi Varma Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: 1959 memo prospective; governs interpretation of 1972 memo.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mervyn Coutinho Ors. v. Collector of Customs, Bombay Ors.
Rabindra Nath Bose Ors. v. Union of India Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Dismissal for inordinate delay to protect accrued rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramchandra Shankar Deodhar Ors. v. State of Maharashtra Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Delay not absolute bar if no third party rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Vasant Jayaram Karnik Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Different standards in seniority violate Art 16 only if shown.
Move court before other rights emerge.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kamini Kumar Das Choudhury v. State of West Bengal Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Demand and refusal needed for mandamus.

precedents_cited.case_name: D.R. Nim v. Union of India

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality in employment; direct enforcement of fundamental rights.

outcome.summary: Writ petitions dismissed for failure to establish Article 16 violation, lack of specificity, and inordinate delay creating equitable rights for juniors; 1972 memo upheld as validly implementing Ravi Varma without disturbing past confirmations/promotions.

key_quotes.text: "The equality of opportunity in a matter relating to employment implies equal treatment to persons similarly situated or in the same category as the petitioner."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of Article 16(1) requiring specific unjust denial.

key_quotes.text: "It would be unjust to deprive the respondents of the rights which have accrued to them. Each person ought to be entitled to sit back and consider that this appointment and promotion effected a long time ago would not be set aside."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies dismissal on laches per Rabindra Nath Bose.
